content.question: (a) Rank the values <math alttext="E sub A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="E sub B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="E sub C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>C</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> from greatest to least. Without using equations, justify your answer using physics principles.

frqParts.text: (a) Rank the values <math alttext="E sub A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="E sub B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="E sub C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>C</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> from greatest to least. Without using equations, justify your answer using physics principles.

(b) Derive an expression for <math alttext="E sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> in terms of <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi></math>, <math alttext="rho sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate. Begin your derivation by writing a fundamental physics principle or an equation from the reference booklet.

Consider a new case where instead of having a uniform volume charge density, the charge density of the sphere varies with the radius of the sphere as given by <math alttext="rho sub sphere, of lowercase r, equals, the fraction with numerator negative rho sub 0, and denominator R, end fraction, times lowercase r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mtext>sphere</mtext></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>r</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mo>−</mo><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mrow><mi>R</mi></mfrac><mi>r</mi></mstyle></math>. In this case, the electric field at Point <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math> is <math alttext="E sub B comma new, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>B,new</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>.(c) Will the value of <math alttext="E sub B comma new, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>B,new</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> be greater than, less than, or equal to the value of <math alttext="E sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>, which was derived in part (b)? Justify your claim with relevant physics principles.

unit.text: 8: Electric Charges, Fields, and Gauss's Law

skill.text: 2.A: Derive a symbolic expression from known quantities by selecting and following a logical mathematical pathway.
